thread.title: GRAINS-Corn falls from 9-mth high, planting delays cap losses

title: GRAINS-Corn falls from 9-mth high, planting delays cap losses
text:
GRAINS-Corn falls from 9-mth high, planting delays cap losses Published 12 Hours Ago Reuters
SYDNEY, May 1 (Reuters) - U.S. corn futures edged lower on Tuesday, retreating from a nine-month high touched in the previous session, though losses were checked as the U.S. Department of Agriculture confirmed planting was lagging market expectations.
FUNDAMENTALS
* The most active corn futures on the Chicago Board Of Trade were down 0.1 percent at $4.00-1/2 by 0213 GMT, having gained 0.5 percent in the previous session when prices hit a high of $4.04 a bushel - the highest since July 21.
* The most active soybean futures were down 0.3 percent at $10.46-1/4 a bushel, having closed down 0.7 percent on Monday.
* The most active wheat futures were down 0.4 percent at $5.08-1/2 a bushel, having closed up 2.4 percent on Monday.
* The U.S. Department of Agriculture said 17 percent of the U.S. corn crop had been planted as of Sunday, behind the five-year average of 27 percent and lagging market forecasts.
* Spring wheat was just 10 percent planted, well behind the five-year average of 36 percent.
* Rains across the Midwest are expected to slow corn planting.
MARKET NEWS
* The dollar held steady near four-month highs on Tuesday, awaiting the Federal Reserve's policy decision and key U.S. employment data due later in the week for fresh cues. Oil prices extended gains on Tuesday, supported by comments from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that he was sure U.S. President Donald Trump would do "the right thing" in reviewing Iran's nuclear deal with western powers.
* Wall Street fell on Monday as healthcare stocks slid and investors worried about rising costs for companies as oil prices rose, although the major indexes eked out a gain in April to snap a two-month losing streak
DATA/EVENT AHEAD (GMT)

(Reporting by Colin Packham; Editing by Biju Dwarakanath)
